javadoc:
AddressObjectMap maintains a mapping between addresses in the program and Objects that have been discovered.

AddressObjectMap uses an ObjectPropertySet to track which addresses belong to which Objects. If a range [addr1,addr2] is assigned to a Object with id ID then -ID will be placed as the property value at addr1 and ID will be placed at addr2. In other words AddressObjectMap marks the beginning of a range belonging to an Object with its id (a positive number) and the end with its id (a negative number). A single address "range" will just have one entry which will contain -objID. It is important to realize that the current implementation of this cache, an address can only belong in one Object. This could have bad effects for BlockModels where code can exist in more than one Object. If this is to be used in that case, one must not just clear an area before adding in a range of addresses. You would need to check if there is anything already defined and store a new index in those places that would represent a multi-block location. An AddressObjectMap instance should only be used to map to addresses contained within a single program. The map should be discard if any changes are made to that programs address map (e.g., removing or renaming overlay spaces).

methods.name: getObjects
methods.comment: Get the objs associated with the given address.

params.name: addr
params.comment: the address at which to get objects.

return.comment: an array of objects at the given address.

methods.name: addObject
methods.comment: Associates the given object with the given set of addresses

params.name: set
params.comment: the set of address to be associated with the object.

methods.name: addObject
methods.comment: Associates the given object with the given range of addresses

params.name: startAddr
params.comment: the first address in the range

params.name: endAddr
params.comment: the last address in the range

methods.name: removeObject
methods.comment: Removes any association with the object and the addresses in the given address set.

params.name: set
params.comment: the set of address from which to remove the object.

methods.name: removeObject
methods.comment: Removes any association with the given object and the given range of addresses.

params.name: obj
params.comment: the object to remove from associations in the given range.

params.name: startAddr
params.comment: the first address in the range.

params.name: endAddr
params.comment: the last address in the range.

methods.name: getObj
methods.comment: Gets the list of objects associated with the given address.

params.name: longAddr
params.comment: the long value of the address.

return.comment: an array of objects that have been associated with the given address

methods.name: addRange
methods.comment:
Adds a range to a object.
 Assumes that the range has already been cleared.

methods.name: removeRange
methods.comment: Removes a range from a object.

name: AddressObjectMap
comment:
AddressObjectMap maintains a mapping between addresses in the program
 and Objects that have been discovered.
 
 AddressObjectMap uses an ObjectPropertySet to track which addresses belong to
 which Objects. If a range [addr1,addr2] is assigned to a Object
 with id ID then -ID will be placed as the property value at
 addr1 and ID will be placed at addr2.
 In other words AddressObjectMap marks the beginning of a range belonging to an
 Object with its id (a positive number) and the end with its
 id (a negative number). A single address "range" will just have one entry
 which will contain -objID.

 It is important to realize that the current implementation of this cache,
 an address can only belong in one Object.  This could have bad effects
 for BlockModels where code can exist in more than one Object.  If this
 is to be used in that case, one must not just clear an area before adding in
 a range of addresses.  You would need to check if there is anything already
 defined and store a new index in those places that would represent a multi-block
 location.

 An AddressObjectMap instance should only be used to map to addresses contained within
 a single program.  The map should be discard if any changes 
 are made to that programs address map (e.g., removing or renaming overlay spaces).
